summary: This document is an internal email chain from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) dated August 19, 2019, containing a compilation of news clips. The primary focus is on articles detailing Jeffrey Epstein's death in jail, the investigation into the circumstances, his legal team's past efforts to influence his sex offender classification in New York, and the filing of his will. It also includes unrelated news summaries on other SDNY cases and matters of interest.

Musumeci was one of Epstein's defense attorneys who corresponded with prosecutors and offered to bring in Barry Krischer.

Both were prosecutors in the Manhattan DA's office who handled the Epstein sex offender designation case.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan. The medical examiner ruled the cause of death was suicide by hanging.

events.title: Epstein's Possible Suicide Attempt
events.description: Epstein was found unconscious in his cell with marks on his neck. The incident was investigated as a possible suicide attempt.

events.title: Epstein Signs Will
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein signed his will, placing his assets into a trust called The 1953 Trust, just two days before his death.

events.title: NY Board Recommends High-Risk Classification
events.description: The New York Board of Examiners of Sex Offenders recommended placing Epstein in the highest-risk category following review of the Palm Beach police report.

events.title: Manhattan DA Consents to Low-Risk Designation
events.description: Prosecutor Jennifer Gaffney informed Epstein's lawyers that the Manhattan DA's office would consent to designating him a low-risk sex offender.

events.title: Court Hearing on Sex Offender Level
events.description: A hearing before Justice Ruth Pickholz where the judge rejected the DA's low-risk recommendation and placed Epstein in the highest-risk category.

events.title: BOP Leadership Shakeup
events.description: Attorney General William Barr removed acting BOP chief Hugh Hurwitz and appointed Kathleen Hawk Sawyer as director following Epstein's suicide.

keyFacts: Epstein's defense attorneys Jay Lefkowitz and Sandra Musumeci successfully persuaded Manhattan prosecutors Jennifer Gaffney and Patrick Egan to initially consent to classifying Epstein as a low-risk sex offender, against the recommendation of the state board.
Epstein signed his will on August 8, 2019, two days before his death, placing his $577+ million estate into a trust.
The night Epstein died, the two guards assigned to his unit failed to check on him every 30 minutes as required and are suspected of falsifying logs; both were working overtime.
Epstein was taken off suicide watch on July 29, 2019, just six days after a possible suicide attempt on July 23, a decision that later drew criticism.
Following Epstein's death, Attorney General William Barr ousted the acting director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons, Hugh Hurwitz, citing 'serious irregularities' at the MCC.
